titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the World House Galleries records, 1927-1991, bulk 1953-1980, in the Archives of American Art AAA.worlhoug
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rihoko Ueno
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Samuel H. Kress Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-01-07T08:18-0500

did.abstract: The records of New York City World House Galleries measure 9.8 linear feet and date from 1927 to 1991, with the bulk of them dating from 1953 to 1980. The collection documents the gallery's general business affairs, sales, and relationships with artists from 1953-1968, and later gifts and sales by founder entrepreneur and art collector Herbert Mayer. Artists for which files are found include Jean Dubuffet, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Paul Klee and Georgio Morandi, among many others. Additional records include correspondence, inventory records, sales and purchase records, records of gifts and auctions, and shipping and consignment records.
did.langmaterial: Danish; French; German; Greek; Italian; Spanish
The bulk of the collection is in English. Other languages include Danish, French, German, Greek, Italian, and Spanish, most of which are in the artist files and shipping statements.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 7 series.

list.item: Series 2: Artist Files, 1927-1991 (4.6 linear feet; Box 1-6, 11, OV 12)
Series 3: Inventory Records, 1953-1986 (0.6 linear feet; Box 6)
Series 4: Sales & Purchases, 1956-1987 (0.4 linear feet; Box 6-7)
Series 5: Gifts, 1970-1987 (0.6 linear feet; Box 7, 11, OV 12)
Series 7: Shipping Statements, 1958, 1968-1986 (1.4 linear feet; Box 9-10)

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The World House Galleries records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records of New York City World House Galleries measure 9.8 linear feet and date from 1927 to 1991, with the bulk of the records dating from 1953 to 1980. The collection documents the gallery's general business affairs, sales, and relationships with artists from 1953-1968, and later gifts and sales by founder entrepreneur and art collector Herbert Mayer. Artists for which files are found include Jean Dubuffet, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Paul Klee and Georgio Morandi, among many others. Additional records include correspondence, inventory records, sales and purchase records, records of gifts and auctions, and shipping and consignment records.
Correspondence is somewhat scattered and concerns administrative matters and business with galleries, collectors, museums, and a few artists.

Artist files contain a variety of documents, such as correspondence, artist statements and resumes, sales records, printed materials, and photographs about artists who were either represented by World House Galleries or in whom the gallery was interested. Artists for which files are found include Jean Dubuffet, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Paul Klee and Georgio Morandi, among many others.

Inventory records include art inventory lists and notes, provenance documentation, and consignment records. Also found are financial records of sales and of purchases made abroad and within the United States.

Documents about Herbert Mayer’s donations to Colgate University and other organizations and institutions, including the Art Students League and Parsons School of Design are in the Gifts series. These records include correspondence, printed materials, and copies of agreements and forms.

Auction records are found for sales through Christie's, Sotheby’s and Parke-Bernet auction houses of World House Galleries art inventory, and Herbert Mayer's personal art collection. This series contains photographs of art, auction catalogs, correspondence, and other miscellaneous materials.
Shipping files contain documents such as statements, customs forms, and correspondence about shipments of art from around the world, mostly from Europe, to World House Galleries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: This collection was fully processed by Rihoko Ueno in February 2013 with funding provided by the Samuel H. Kress Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: World House Galleries records, 1927-1991, bulk 1953-1980. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The World House Galleries records were donated in 2002 by Herbert Mayer, Jr., son of gallery founder Herbert Mayer.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: World House Galleries was founded by Herbert Mayer, Sr. in 1953 in New York City. The gallery operated until 1968, representing an eclectic group of artists from around the world.

Herbert Mayer (circa 1911-1993) was a lawyer, businessman and owner of the World House Galleries in New York City. He attended Colgate University in Hamilton, New York where he majored in English and graduated in 1929. After graduation, he traveled through Europe with Colgate English Professor Russell Speirs and the four months he spent in Paris studying art at the Louvre was a formative experience for Mayer. He went on to attend law school at the University of Wisconsin. He was lawyer in New York until the early 1940s, then began selling television sets which were more familiar to the U.S. public after the 1939 World’s Fair. In 1944, Mayer stopped practicing law and became a television magnate. He founded the Empire Coil Company, which manufactured radiofrequency coils for television sets and stations. From 1949 through 1952, Mayer launched television stations in Cleveland, Ohio; Portland, Oregon; and Kansas City, Missouri.

In 1953, Mayer bid farewell to the world of television and founded the World House Galleries. The gallery was located on Madison Avenue in New York City’s Carlyle Hotel, occupying a total of 6,900 square feet on two floors. Architect Frederick Kiesler was commissioned to design the space. Mayer’s goal was to attract a wider audience to contemporary international art and, in his words, “express the thinking and feeling of contemporary artists everywhere — wherever unusual talent is discovered.” Mayer worked closely with Colgate Professor Alfred Krakusin, who became the gallery advisor, and the two frequently traveled together in search of new art. On his trips abroad, Mayer also purchased art for his personal collection.

World House Galleries represented an eclectic group of European artists such as Jean Dubuffet, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Paul Klee and Georgio Morandi in addition to lesser known artists. World House Galleries exhibitions included art for sale within the gallery, as well as art loaned from private collections and museums. The gallery represented an eclectic group of artists from Austria, France, Finland, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Norway, Spain and Sweden. Mayer and Krakusin also collaborated on Sculptura, a business which created bronze casts of statues and plaques to be sold at the gallery.

World House Galleries had strong ties with Colgate University and Mayer arranged numerous exhibitions at his alma mater between 1956 and 1962. The exhibitions were held in the basement of Lawrence Hall and showcased art from World House Galleries and Mayer’s personal collection. In 1958, Mayer donated the first of many gifts of art to Colgate University. His largest gift of almost 2000 paintings, sculptures, and drawings occurred in 1967 and became the core collection for what is now known as Colgate’s Picker Art Gallery.

After World House Galleries closed in 1968 Herbert Mayer continued to sell art through auction houses and galleries as well as make donations to Colgate and various other organizations through the 1980s. In early 1971, Mayer contacted Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. to arrange an auction of artwork from his personal collection. The bulk of his collection was sold through Parke-Bernet in 1984.

Mayer died in 1991, survived by his wife, Bet, and their five children. Through exhibitions which showcased art from different countries, World House Galleries exposed the New York art world to a more diverse vision of international modernism.

controlaccess.subject: Art galleries, Commercial -- New York (State) -- New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of somewhat scattered business and administrative correspondence with clients, collectors, museums, galleries, auction houses, and a few artists. Correspondence concerns art purchases, loans to other galleries, and requests for Mayer to view art or visit artist studios. Some of the correspondence includes attached artist resumes. There is some additional correspondence scattered throughout the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artist files contain a variety of material on artists who were represented by World House Galleries or in whom the gallery was interested. Artist files hold correspondence, artist statements and resumes, sales records, printed materials, and exhibition catalogs. Most of the files also include images of the artist and of the artist's work in the form of slides, transparencies, negatives, and photographs. Prominent artists represented by the gallery and for which files exist include Jean Dubuffet, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Paul Klee and Georgio Morandi, in addition to many artists from around the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inventory records include gallery stock inventories, lists of art on consignment, and provenance notes. There are rough and final drafts of inventory organized by category, such as Herman Mayer’s personal collection and the Oriental Antiquities collection, in addition to folders on specific items in the World House Galleries inventory organized by the artist's name.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The inventories for collections are arranged chronologically, with the "obsolete" or outdated rough drafts grouped together at the beginning. The inventories are followed by a list of art on consignment, then the item level folders for inventory arranged by alphabetically by the artist's last name. Inventory and provenance notes are at the end of the series.

did.unittitle: Inventory Items, Maestro di San Miniato

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records of sales and purchases consist of sales records, financial documentation of accounts receivable or payments owed for sales of artwork, and documentation of Herbert Mayer's purchases, both abroad and within the United States. The sales records include cost and sales price and date from the founding of the gallery in 1953 until several years after it closed. Also found in this series are correspondence, lists of purchases, appraisals, auction catalogs, and printed materials.

did.unittitle: Notes for Purchases Abroad by Herbert Mayer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sereis contains documents about Herbert Mayer’s donations to various schools, organizations and programs after World House Galleries closed. Mayer was very generous to his alma mater, Colgate University, and he donated art from the gallery and his personal collection, along with large tracts of land in Maine. Mayer also made substantial donations to other organizations and institutions, such as the Art Students League, Parsons School of Design, and the Stamford Center of the Jewish Community. Files include correspondence, forms and papers about the gifts, photographs, and printed materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series holds records related to art work sold through Christie's, Parke-Bernet 84 (a division of Parke-Bernet), and Sotheby's auction houses in New York City. Herbert Mayer sold some art through the auction houses while World House Galleries was open and disseminated the majority of his personal art collection after the gallery closed. The folders contain correspondence, receipts, consignment agreements, settlement statements, lists of art available through the auction houses and other miscellanous materials.

did.unittitle: Christie's London, Persian Pottery, Coins, Sculpture
Parke-Bernet 84, African and Other Ethnic Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Retained the original folder title from the collection. Most of the documents are on African Art, but there are also records titled "Miscellaneous - Coptic, Oceanic, Egyptian, Chinese, Indian, Mexican, African, Etc." which contain lists of items from various countries.

did.unittitle: Parke-Bernet 84, Claims for Missing Asian Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material from Box 8, Folder 14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Shipping statement files contain customs forms, correspondence, complaints, condition reports, and other documents related to the transportation and shipping of art work. Most of the files track specific shipments of art from locations around the world to their destination at World House Galleries in New York City.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by the country of the shipment's origin, then chronologically by year. There are a few files with the same dates from the same location that actually represent different shipments. order.

There are a few miscellaneous folders at the end of the series labeled according to the contents of the shipment, such as ceramics, or the approximate timeframe of a trip abroad during which Herbert Mayber bought art for shipment.
